title: 113_hr1123
content: The Act is titled the "Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act." It repeals an existing rule and allows for additional rulemaking by the Librarian of Congress. As of the enactment of the "Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act," a specific paragraph in the Code of Federal Regulations will be repealed and replaced to its previous version from July 27, 2010. The Librarian of Congress, in consultation with the Register of Copyrights, will determine whether to extend certain requirements under title 17, United States Code. The Librarian of Congress, in consultation with the Register of Copyrights, will decide whether to expand the exemption for certain works under title 17, United States Code to include additional wireless devices. The timing of this decision depends on the enactment date of the Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act. The Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act allows for the circumvention of technological measures restricting wireless devices from connecting to a network, as authorized by specific regulations or exemptions granted by the Librarian of Congress under title 17, United States Code. The Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act permits unlocking of wireless devices for connection to a network, authorized by the owner, a family member, or a service provider. Bulk unlocking for resale purposes is not allowed under this provision. The Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act allows unlocking of wireless devices for connection to a network, but prohibits bulk unlocking for resale. The Act does not change the authority of the Librarian of Congress under section 1201(a)(1) of title 17, United States Code. Definitions in the Act include terms like commercial mobile data service, commercial mobile radio service, and wireless telecommunications network. The terms "wireless telephone handset" and "wireless device" refer to devices that operate on a wireless telecommunications network. The House of Representatives passed the bill on February 25, 2014. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
